facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 230 of 1956 appealed by special leave from Orissa High Court judgment dated April 12, 1955 in O.J.C. No. 60 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 230 of 1956. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 12, 1955, of the Orissa High Court in 0. J. C. No. 60 of 1952.

facts.text: Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Orissa XIV of 1947) received assent of Governor-General on April 26, 1947, with s.1 coming into force then.

anchor.surface_text: The Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947  Orissa XIV of 1947 , hereinafter referred to as the said Act received the assent of the Governor-General on April 26, 1947, when s. I of the Act came into force.

facts.text: Notification issued on August 1, 1947 bringing rest of Orissa Sales Tax Act into force in Province of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1947, a Notification was issued by the Government of Orissa bringing the rest of the said Act into force in the Province of Orissa, as it was then companystituted.

facts.text: Feudatory State of Pallahara merged into Province of Orissa on January 1, 1948 by covenant of merger executed by its ruler.

anchor.surface_text: On January 1, 1948, by a companyenant of merger executed by its ruler, the feudatory State of Pallahara merged into the province of Orissa.

facts.text: Government of Orissa issued notification on December 14, 1948 under s.4 of Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947 extending Orissa Sales Tax Act to territories including Pallahara.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers delegated to it by the Government of India under what was then known as the Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947, the Government of Orissa on December 14, 1948, issued a numberification under s. 4 of that Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, extending the Orissa Sales Tax Act to the territories of the erstwhile feudatory States, including Pallahara which had merged into the province of Orissa.

facts.text: Notification under s.1(3) issued March 1, 1949 bringing ss.2 to 29 of Orissa Sales Tax Act into force in added territories.

anchor.surface_text: On March 1, 1949, a numberification under s. 1 3  was issued by the Government of Orissa bringing ss. 2 to 29 of the said Act into force in the added territories.

facts.text: Notification under s.4(1) on March 1, 1949 appointing March 31, 1949 as date from which dealers with gross turnover exceeding Rs.5000 in year ending March 31, 1949 liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day another numberification was issued under s. 4 1  of the Act, which was in the following terms In exercise of the powers companyferred by Sub-section  1  of Section 4 of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947  Orissa Act XIV of 1947  as applied to Orissa State, the Government of Orissa are pleased to appoint the 31st March, 1949, as the date with effect from which every dealer whose gross turnover during the year ending the 31st March, 1949, exceeded Rs. 5,000 shall be liable to pay tax under the said Act on sales effected after the said date.

facts.text: Respondents assessed under Act for five quarters ending September 30, 1949; December 31, 1949; June 30, 1950; September 30, 1950; December 31, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents were assessed under the said Act for five quarters ending respectively on September 30, 1949, December 31, 1949, June 30, 1950, September 30, 1950, and December 31, 1950.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack assessed respondents; appeals dismissed April 12, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack having assessed the respondents to Sales Tax under the said Act for each and all of the said five quarters and the respondents several appeals against the said several assessment orders under the said Act having been dismissed on April 12, 1952,

facts.text: Respondents filed Art.226 petition in Orissa High Court praying for certiorari to quash assessments and prohibition.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the Orissa High Court praying, inter alia, for a writ in the nature of a writ of certiorari for quashing the said assessment orders and for prohibiting the appellants from realising the tax so assessed or from making assessments on them in future.

facts.text: Orissa High Court by judgment April 12, 1955 cancelled the assessments accepting respondent's contentions on notification invalidity and Art.286.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted both these companytentions and by its judgment and order pronounced on April 12, 1955, cancelled the assessments.

facts.text: Respondent is partnership firm B.C. Patel & Co. carrying business of collection and sale of Kendu leaves at Pallahara.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, Messrs.B. C. Patel and Co., is a partnership firm carrying on the business of companylection and sale of Kendu leaves. The firm has its headquarters at Pallahara,

facts.text: Respondent collected Kendu leaves in Orissa, sold to merchants in Calcutta, Madras etc. on orders; goods sent f.o.r. Talcher or Calcutta; bills sent for payment; delivered for consumption outside Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The facts which the Sales Tax authorities found were  I.  that the respondent companylected Kendu leaves in Orissa and sold them to various merchants of Calcutta, Madras and other places on receipt of orders from them,  2  that the goods were sent either f. o. r. Talcher or f. o. r. Calcutta, and  3  the sale price was realised by sending the bills to the purchasers for payment. The admitted position was that the goods were delivered for companysumption at various places out- side the State of Orissa.

facts.text: It was conceded that for period April 1, 1949 to Jan 26, 1950 respondents liable if valid notification under s.4(1).

anchor.surface_text: But a remand is number called for because it appears from the judgment under appeal that it was companyceded that for the period April 1, 1949, till the companymencement of the Constitution on January 26, 1950, the respondents would have been liable to pay sales tax provided a valid numberification had been issued, under sub-s.  1  of s.

facts.text: Supreme Court held notification under s.4(1) valid only for appointing March 31, 1949 as date; invalid for specifying wrong year; severable.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the numberification, in so far as it appointed March 31, 1949, as the date with effect from which liability to pay tax would companymence was valid and the rest of the numberification was invalid and must be treated as surplus without any legal efficacy.

facts.text: Supreme Court held assessments for two pre-Constitution quarters valid under s.4(2).

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that all the requirements of sub-s.  2  are fulfilled in this case, and the two assessment orders made against the respondent for the pre- Constitution period were validly made under sub-s.  2  of s. 4 of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held assessments for three post-Constitution quarters invalid due to Art.286(1) and s.30(1)(a)(i).

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in companyplete agreement with  1  1953 S.C.R. 1069. our learned Brother S. K. Das J. for reasons stated by him that the assessment orders for the three post Constitution quarters were hit by cl.  1  of Art. 286 and also s. 30  1   a   1  of the Act and were rightly held by the High Court to be without jurisdiction.

facts.text: Notification for old province on August 14, 1947 appointing September 30, 1947 under s.4(1).

anchor.surface_text: On August 14, 1947, a numberification was issued by the Government of Orissa appointing September 30, 1947, as the date with effect from which that sub-section was to companye into force in the then province of Orissa.

facts.text: Year immediately preceding commencement of Act in added territories was April 1, 1947 to March 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: for in either case the year immediately preceding the companymencement of this Act was April 1, 1947, to March 31, 1948.

facts.text: Special leave to appeal granted January 17, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal on behalf of the assessing authorities, Cuttack, has been brought pursuant to an order made on January 17, 1956, granting them special leave to appeal to this Court

facts.text: Assessments dated May 31, 1951 by Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack.

anchor.surface_text: By five separate assessment orders dated May 31, 1951, the Sales Tax Officer, Cuttack, held that the sales having taken place in Orissa,

facts.text: Appeals affirmed by Assistant Collector April 12, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: These findings were affirmed by the Assistant Collector of Sales Tax, Orissa, on appeal, by his order dated April 12, 1952.

facts.text: Respondent filed Art.226 petition November 11, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: They then applied to the High Court of Orissa on November 11. 1952, for an appro- priate writ

facts.text: Sales Tax authorities found sales took place in Orissa despite delivery outside.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales Tax authorities proceeded on the footing that all the sales took place in Orissa even though the goods were delivered for company sumption at places outside Orissa.

facts.text: Gross turnover of respondents exceeded Rs.5000 in year ending March 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: What was found was that the respondents gross turnover exceeded Rs. 5,000 in 1948-49, that is, the year ending March 31,, 1949,

issues.text: Whether the notification dated March 1, 1949 issued under s.4(1) of the Orissa Sales Tax Act is valid or wholly invalid due to specifying the wrong year for turnover calculation?

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers conferred by Sub-section 1 of Section 4 of the Orissa Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Orissa Act XIV of 1947) as applied to Orissa State, the Government of Orissa are pleased to appoint the 31st March, 1949, as the date with effect from which every dealer whose gross turnover during the year ending the 31st March, 1949, exceeded Rs. 5,000 shall be liable to pay tax under the said Act on sales effected after the said date.

issues.text: Whether the invalid portion of the notification under s.4(1) specifying the wrong turnover year is severable from the valid portion appointing the date March 31, 1949?

anchor.surface_text: The question that immediately arises is as to whether the whole notification should be adjudged invalid as has been done by the High Court and as is proposed to be done by my learned Brother S. K. Das J. or the two portions of the notification should be severed and effect should be given to the earlier part which is in conformity with s. 4 1 and the latter part which goes beyond the powers conferred by the subsection to the Government of Orissa should be rejected.

issues.text: Whether the assessments for the two pre-Constitution quarters are valid under s.4(2) of the Orissa Sales Tax Act even if s.4(1) does not apply?

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that all the requirements of sub-s. 2 are fulfilled in this case, and the two assessment orders made against the respondent for the pre- Constitution period

anchor.surface_text: by reason of the provisions of Art. 286 of the Constitution. The High Court accepted both these contentions

arguments.claim: Notification not severable; mistake makes whole invalid

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that it can be severed in the way suggested by the learned Solicitor General.

arguments.claim: s.4(1) and s.4(2) mutually exclusive only by relevant periods; s.4(2) applies here

anchor.surface_text: Sub- sections  1  and  2  are mutually, exclusive only in the sense that they do not operate in the same field that is, the relevant periods for their application are different.

arguments.claim: Continuance Order subject to Art.286(1)(a); does not save sales outside state

anchor.surface_text: This non obstante clause does not, in terms, supersede clause  1  at all and, therefore, prima facie, the Presidents order was subject to the prohibition of clause  1   a  read with the Explanation.

holdings.text: The notification under s.4(1) is valid insofar as it appoints March 31, 1949 as the date from which tax liability commences; the rest specifying turnover in year ending March 31, 1949 is invalid and severable as surplusage.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the notification, in so far as it appointed March 31, 1949, as the date with effect from which liability to pay tax would commence was valid and the rest of the notification was invalid and must be treated as surplus without any legal efficacy.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government power limited to appointing date; class of dealers determined by statute; invalid part independent and severable without affecting valid part.

holdings.text: The notification under s.4(1) is wholly invalid as it does not conform to the statutory requirement of referencing the year immediately preceding commencement of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that it can be severed in the way suggested by the learned Solicitor General.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification must comply fully with sub-section requirements; mistake in relevant period makes it non-conforming; severance not possible as suggested.

holdings.text: Assessments for two pre-Constitution quarters valid under s.4(2) as respondent's gross turnover first exceeded Rs.5000 during 1948-49, liability from April 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that all the requirements of sub-s.  2  are fulfilled in this case, and the two assessment orders made against the respondent for the pre- Constitution period were validly made under sub-s.  2  of s. 4 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4(1) and s.4(2) operate in different fields based on relevant periods; turnover exceeded in 1948-49 after Act commencement, no notification needed for s.4(2).

holdings.text: Assessments for three post-Constitution quarters invalid as hit by Art.286(1) and s.30(1)(a)(i) since sales outside Orissa (delivery for consumption outside).

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in complete agreement with our learned Brother S. K. Das J. for reasons stated by him that the assessment orders for the three post Constitution quarters were hit by cl.  1  of Art. 286 and also s. 30 1   a   1  of the Act and were rightly held by the High Court to be without jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Goods delivered for consumption outside Orissa per Explanation to Art.286(1)(a); s.30 mirrors it; confirmed by Bengal Immunity Co.

holdings.text: Sales Tax Continuance Order 1950 does not override prohibition in Art.286(1)(a) as non-obstante clause subject to cl.1(a) and Explanation.

anchor.surface_text: This non obstante clause does not, in terms, supersede clause  1  at all and, therefore, prima facie, the Presidents order was subject to the prohibition of clause  1   a  read with the Explanation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to Art.286(2) non-obstante applies only to cl.2; separate bans in Art.286; Bengal Immunity holds cl.1(a) prevails for outside sales.

holdings.text: Year immediately preceding commencement of Act in added territories (Pallahara) is financial year April 1, 1947 to March 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: for in either case the year immediately preceding the commencement of this Act was April 1, 1947, to March 31, 1948.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Commencement either Dec 14, 1948 (extension) or March 1, 1949 (s.1(3)); preceding year same financial year 1947-48 per s.2(j).

holdings.text: Respondent's gross turnover exceeded Rs.5000 in year ending March 31, 1949 (1948-49).

anchor.surface_text: What was found was that the respondents gross turnover exceeded Rs. 5,000 in 1948-49, that is, the year ending March 31,, 1949,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Finding by sales tax authorities affirmed; conceded for liability if valid notification.

holdings.text: Concession that respondents liable for period April 1, 1949 to Jan 26, 1950 if valid s.4(1) notification implies turnover exceeded in preceding year 1947-48.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admission in High Court judgment that liability if valid notification equates to turnover exceeding in correct preceding year.

precedents.citation: State of Bombay v. United Motors India Ltd. 1 ... 1 1953 S.C.R. 1069

anchor.surface_text: As regards the assessment orders for the three post Constitution quarters, the decision of the High Court purports to have proceeded on the decision of this Court in the State of Bombay v. United Motors India Ltd. 1 . We find ourselves in complete agreement with 1 1953 S.C.R. 1069.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Assessments for post-Constitution quarters invalid under Article 286(1) as sales deemed outside the state
precedents.cited_holding: Sale where goods delivered for consumption outside state takes place outside state by Explanation to Art. 286(1)

precedents.citation: The State of Bombay v. The United Motors India Ltd. 1 ... 1 1953 S.C.R. 1069

anchor.surface_text: the decision of this Court in The State of Bombay v. The United Motors India Ltd. 1 Said the High Court Clause 1 of Article 286 prohibited a State from taxing a sale unless such sale took place within the State as explained in the Explanation to the clause of the Article. Similarly, clause 2 of that Article restricted the power of a State to tax a sale which took place in the course of inter-State trade or commerce. 1 1953 S.C.R. 1069.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. United Motors (India) Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Art. 286(1) prohibits taxing sales outside state; Explanation deems sale at delivery for consumption; applies to inter-state elements where delivery outside
precedents.cited_holding: State cannot tax sales involving inter-State elements where goods delivered for consumption outside the state

precedents.citation: The Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. The State of Bihar and Others 1 ... 1 1955 2 S.C.R. 603

anchor.surface_text: in a later decision of this Court in The Bengal Immunity Company Limited v. The State of Bihar and Others 1 , which was, not available to the High Court when it delivered its judgment, the view expressed in the United Motors, case 2 was departed from in so far as the earlier decision held that cl. 2 of Art. 286 of the Constitution did not affect the power of the State in which delivery of goods was made to tax inter-State sales or purchases of the kind mentioned in the Explanation to cl. 1 and the effect of the Explanation was that such transactions were saved from the ban imposed by Art. 286 2 . 1 1955 2 S.C.R. 603. 2 1953 S.C.R. 1069.

precedents.case_name: Bengal Immunity Company Ltd. v. State of Bihar
